Pre-application fees

Householder Applications and Minor Works to Non-Residential Property

Householder Applications
Enlargement, improvement, or other alteration to a dwelling and incidental development within the garden including garages and outbuildings. This class does not include erection of a new house(s) in the garden.

Minor Works to non-residential property
For example, awnings, solar panels, windows, adverts, small ancillary development up to 100 square metres including extensions, sheds, bicycle racks, decking, cladding, flues, extractors, and pumps

Householder Applications and Minor Works to Non-Residential Property fees

Types of adviceFee (inc. VAT)
Written£265

Listed building/heritage with Conservation Officer only

Listed building advice/specific advice about impact on a conversation area or other heritage asset
Note: if you would like planning and listed building/heritage advice you will need to apply for the relevant planning advice type and request the conservation officer as an additional specialist subject to an additional fee. 
Please be aware if you have requested listed building/heritage advice with a conservation officer only, their response will not consider the merits of any planning permission that may also be required. This can influence the consideration of your planning application beyond the heritage advice you receive.

Listed building/heritage with Conservation Officer only fees

Types of adviceFee (inc. VAT)
Written£220
Site based meeting and write up. (At officers’ discretion as to whether a site-based meeting is required)£510
If your enquiry is of a more complex nature, we reserve the right to provide a bespoke fee.Bespoke based on hourly rate £113 per hour or part thereof

Minor Works (Non-householder) *

*Note: the term ‘residential units’ includes accommodation use for holiday lets

Small minor:

  • the replacement or erection of or, change of use to create 1 or 2 residential units or conversion of building(s) to 1 or 2 residential units
  • non-residential schemes for new buildings/extensions to existing buildings; 200 to 499 square metres floorspace
  • erection of or works to agricultural buildings or land
  • change of use of land only
  • telecoms proposals

Small works fees

Types of adviceFee (inc. VAT)
Written£625
Site based meeting and write up (At officers’ discretion as to whether a site-based meeting is required)£990

Minor:

  • the replacement or erection of, or change of use to create between 3 to 9 residential units
  • non-residential schemes for new buildings or extensions to existing buildings 500 up to1000 square metres floorspace
  • small scale free standing renewable energy proposals under 1 hectare

Minor works fees

Types of adviceFee (inc. VAT)
Written£880
Site based meeting and write up (At officers’ discretion as to whether a site-based meeting is required)£1165

Major Applications

Types of development:

Small scale major:

  • the replacement, or erection of, or change of use to create10 to 24 residential units
  • residential development, or mixed use on a site area up to 2 hectares
  • non-residential schemes for new buildings/extensions more than 1,000 up to 4,999 square metres floorspace or on a site area between 1 - 2 hectare
  • small scale free standing renewable energy proposals over 1 hectare

Small scale major fees

Types of adviceFee (inc. VAT)
Written£1315
Office based meeting and write up£1490
Site based meeting and write up (At officers’ discretion as to whether a site-based meeting is required)£1830

Medium scale major

Medium scale major are:

  • the replacement or, erection of, or change of use to create 25 to 149 residential units
  • residential development or mixed use on a site area 2 to 4 hectares
  • non-residential schemes for new buildings/extensions 5,000 up to 9,999 square metres floorspace or on a site area between 2 to 4 hectare

Medium scale major fees

Types of adviceFee (inc. VAT)
Written£2490
Office based meeting and write up£2725
Site based meeting and write up (At officers’ discretion as to whether a site-based meeting is required)£2965

Large scale major

Large scale major are:

  • the replacement or, erection of, or change of use to create 150 or more residential units
  • residential development or a mixed use on a site area greater than 4 hectares
  • non-residential schemes for new buildings/extensions 10,000 square metres or more floorspace or on a site area greater than 4 hectares

All environmental impact assessment development

Large scale major fees

Types of adviceFee (inc. VAT)
WrittenBespoke fee based on hourly rate £123 per hour or part there or use a PPA
Office based meeting and write up
Site based meeting and write up (At officers’ discretion as to whether a site-based meeting is required)

Minerals and Waste

Type of development

Level 1

Including but not limited to:

  • plant machinery for the processing, treatment or production of minerals or any mineral derived product on a site less than 1 hectare
  • searches and tests of mineral deposits
  • building or buildings less than 1000 square metres
  • change of use of buildings or land
  • winning and working of minerals on area less than 1 hectare
  • landfill or land-raising on area less than 1 hectare
  • non-residential development where land is, or forms part of, a site formerly used for the winning and working of minerals and has not been fully restored
  • application under Section 73 of the 1990 Act not involving time extension to complete development

Mineral waste fees

Types of adviceFee (inc. VAT)
Office / virtual or site-based meeting, and write up£2370

Level 2

Including but not limited to:

  • environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) development;
  • winning and working of minerals on area greater than 1 hectare
  • plant and machinery for the processing, treatment or production of minerals or any mineral derived product or article on site more than 1 hectare
  • landfill or land-raising on an area greater than 1 hectare
  • restoration of mineral workings
  • waste recovery, treatment, storage, processing, sorting, and transfer on an open site;
  • buildings or building for use more than 1000 square metres
  • disposal of mineral waste
  • application under Section 73 of the 1990 Act for minor material amendment where the original permission was for development involving any of the above

Level 2 mineral waste fees

Types of adviceFee (inc. VAT)
Office / virtual or site-based meeting, and write up£3080

Other advice minerals and waste

The Minerals & Waste Team can provide informal verbal advice (up to 30 minutes) in relation to likely information required to support pre-application requests or validate planning applications and to discuss pre-application responses. More detailed advice would incur a fee which shall be agreed and paid in advance of a meeting or written response.
Such advice includes, but is not limited to:

  • discussion of consultee requirements including outcome of EIA screening and scoping
  • planning matters relating to minerals and waste sites

Provide and facilitate feedback where draft documents to support a planning application (For example, ES chapters or standalone documents) have been submitted.

Other minerals and waste fees

Types of adviceFee (inc. VAT)
Please contact the Minerals and Waste Team to agree the type of advice and a feeBespoke fee based on hourly rate £113 per hour or part thereof

Other types of development and follow up advice

Types of development:

Other types of development fees

Types of development Types of advice Fee (inc. VAT)
All other types of development not included above Any Contact for the bespoke quotation
Advice to a parish or town council relating to development they will commission/undertake Any Half the normal pre-ap fee
Advice relating to development specifically for the benefit/use of disabled persons. (A disabled person is one to whom Section 29 of the National Assistance Act 1948 applies or a child who is disabled for the purposes of part III of the Children Act 1989. A medical practitioner's certificate may be required in some cases) Any Free
Advice to affordable housing/community land trust Any Subject to full charges as set out above dependent on the development type
Follow up advice. If you need additional advice or would like to discuss the advice, we have given.   Written (At officers’ discretion if you would like to discuss the advice) Based on hourly rate £113 per hour or part thereof
Standalone review and advice of ecology information and surveys and/or Biodiversity Net Gain information provided by Senior Ecologist, Natural Environment Team only Written If your enquiry is of a more complex nature, we reserve the right to provide a bespoke fee. £500 Bespoke based on hourly rate £113.00 per hour or part thereof.

Planning Performance Agreements and Specialist team officer advice

Other types of services

Types services Types of advice Fee (inc. VAT)
Planning Performance Agreements (PPAs) Any Based on officer time and will be charged at £123 per hour or part thereof.
Planning Performance Agreements (PPAs) Any An additional charge at an hourly rate of £123 per hour or part thereof will apply for each specialist team officer who is required to attend a meeting or provide a consultation response as part of your pre application enquiry.
Design Review Panel Any We will provide a bespoke quote for our time on request at a rate of £123 per hour or part thereof.

 
Please note: the fees listed are for advice from a planning officer only. If input from a specialist officer is needed, there will be an additional charge.

Making payments

Payments can be made in the following ways:

  • By following the instructions online when you submit your pre-application request or householder permitted development enquiry.
  • By card payment over the phone.

We no longer accept cheques as payment. All fees must be paid on submission of your request.

View more detail about our pre app service and other services we offer.

Service Charge for returned unvalidated application

We will work with you to get your application validated but there might be cases where an application is not pursued or withdrawn. In these circumstances, we would retain an administrative charge.  Charges will be applied according to the fee incurred.

Planning application fee Invalid application charge
£0 to £99£0
£100 to £500£35
£501 to £749£75
£750 to £2499£155
£2500 £250

Notes:

  • floorspace refers to gross external floorspace
  • the larger element of a mixed-use scheme will primarily be used to determine which category of fee applies to the proposal
  • for the purposes of charging, flats and holiday accommodation are considered as houses
  • fees will be subject to periodic review, normally annually
  • the charge applies to advice received from Dorset Council officers only
  • charges apply to pre-application advice for unauthorised development where works have already been carried out and may or not be subject to an enforcement investigation or enforcement action

ai_business_case.letter:
To: CEO  
From: Web Usability & Service Efficiency Team  

Subject: Recommendations for Improving Flat Improvement Permissions Process Based on Customer Feedback  

Dear CEO,  

After reviewing the recent customer feedback, needs analysis, and existing webpage content related to applying for permission to make changes to council flats, I have identified specific opportunities to enhance our online service. These improvements could significantly streamline the user experience, increase application success rates, reduce staff time spent on clarifications, and ultimately deliver cost savings to the council.  

**Summary of Findings:**  
- The current webpage heavily emphasizes fees and technical planning application details, which are less relevant for tenants seeking straightforward permission for simple home upgrades like installing a handrail or replacing a kitchen.  
- Feedback explicitly indicates that users find the information confusing and would prefer clear, step-by-step guidance tailored to their needs.  
- The absence of direct links to simplified online forms leads to friction, potentially causing delays or drop-offs in the application process.  

**Recommended Improvements:**  
1. **Simplify Content Focus:**  
   - Develop a dedicated, easy-to-understand section or webpage for tenants requesting permissions for small flat improvements.  
   - Emphasize that these are simple, low-cost upgrades that do not require detailed planning applications.  

2. **Implement Clear, Step-by-Step Guidance:**  
   - Create a straightforward guide outlining each step, e.g.:  
     1. Visit the online application form link specific to flat improvements.  
     2. Fill out a brief form with basic details about the upgrade (e.g., installation of a handrail or kitchen modification).  
     3. Upload photos or plans if necessary.  
     4. Submit the request and receive confirmation with follow-up timelines.  
   - Include estimated response times and reassure tenants about the process.  

3. **Add Direct, User-Friendly Links:**  
   - Place prominent buttons or links labeled "Apply for flat improvements" directly on the housing services homepage.  
   - Ensure the link leads to a simplified, pre-populated online form designed for non-technical users.  

4. **Use Plain Language and Visual Aids:**  
   - Avoid technical planning language; instead, use plain, accessible language.  
   - Incorporate icons or diagrams illustrating the process to make the steps more intuitive.  

**Impact of These Improvements:**  
- **Enhanced Customer Satisfaction:** Tenants will feel confident navigating the process and more likely to complete applications independently.  
- **Operational Efficiency:** Fewer inquiries and clarifications from tenants will reduce staff workload, allowing them to focus on complex cases.  
- **Cost Savings:** Streamlined digital processes decrease reliance on paper communications and handling manual requests, reducing administrative costs.  
- **Better Engagement:** Clear guidance fosters trust and demonstrates our commitment to responsive, user-centric service.  

**Conclusion:**  
Implementing these targeted improvements aligns with best practices in digital service design by prioritizing user needs and reducing unnecessary complexity. I recommend prioritizing the creation of a simplified, accessible pathway for tenants seeking permission for flat improvements. This approach will advance our service efficiency, improve customer experience, and deliver measurable cost savings.  

Please let me know how you'd like to proceed or if you require a detailed action plan.  

Best regards,  
[Web Manager Name]  
Usability & Service Efficiency Lead
